name: Avoid using the Hints to force Oracle to use a specific access method (PeopleSoft)
description:
This quality rule reports SQL Definitions using an Oracle Hint in the SQL statement.
It detects the specific start of comment '/*+' without further checks on the hint syntax.
rationale:
To force Oracle to use a specific access method a common practive is to use the Hints. But do so knowingly (Oracle will not use the right index...) and be aware of the consequences (if tomorrow the indexes change, you may degrade database performance without knowing).
So, when you know what you are doing, you might use the hints....as the last chance tuning.
OTOH and for instance, for certain SQL constructs, the use of the FIRST_ROWS hint can severely degrade performance.

This quality rule reports all SQL definition using an Oracle hint, in order to help a senior DBA check if the hints are effective.
reference:
Oracle Database Performance Tuning Guide: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14211/hintsref.htm#i8327
PeopleSoft Application Server Domain Parameter OracleDisableFirstRowsHint :https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E13292_01/pt849pbr0/eng/psbooks/tsvt/chapter.htm?File=tsvt/htm/tsvt05.htm%23g037ee99c9453fb39_ef90c_10c791ddc07_ec7
remediation:
No generic remediation, this is a report for information and deep manual review.
If the Oracle hint degrades the performance, remove it.
If it is not effective, then adapt the hint (using tkprof for instance) to make it effective.
sample:
The Hints are enclosed in comment :
{DELETE|INSERT|SELECT|UPDATE} /*+ hint [text] [hint[text]]... */
located between the SELECT clause and the first column in the list.

SELECT  /*+ parallel (4) */ TO_CHAR(D.PAY_BEGIN_DT,:"SYS_B_000"),………
